description.narrative: ITPC’s Missing the Target (MTT) research series aims to support civil society advocates to monitor the delivery of HIV services in their countries and hold national governments and other stakeholders accountable to ensuring quality treatment access for all in need. The MTT process includes the provision of funds for community-level research and advocacy as well as training for participating local organisations. Outputs include MTT research reports and advocacy activities based on the findings that are undertaken by the organisations in parallel with the report’s preparation and after its release. In 2016, country partners in Tajikistan and Pakistan will begin an MTT project to identify the conditions under which PUDs in each country can be adherent to ARVs. This will have a special focus on the political factors that impact these conditions, as well as the community-level factors that impact these conditions. In Pakistan, research and advocacy will be carried out by country partners with support from MAINline. In Tajikistan, research and advocacy will be carried out by country partners with support from AFEW. Each country may have further focus their research (per discussions during country Launch Trainings; see below) but will operate under this broader theme with guidance from ITPC – ultimately helping to share lessons learned and best practices.

To support civil society advocates to monitor the delivery of HIV services in their countries and hold national governments and other stakeholders accountable to ensuring quality treatment access for all in need.
We expect to train 10 data collectors We expect to reach 200 KP respondents We expect to reach 2 local CSOs as country teams

activity-date.narrative: Development of report, issue brief and advocacy tool: upon completion of research follow-up, country teams will submit reports using provided templates. These will include narrative, financial and key indicator reports. Reports from each country team will be consolidated into a single external report and issue brief to be published and disseminated widely. Based on the timeline below, publication and dissemination of the final report would strategically coincide with IAC 2018 in Amsterdam. Advocacy: Country teams will also develop an advocacy plan and tool, either based on agreements made during Launch Training or inspired by outcomes of the research. Country teams will begin targeted advocacy activities utilizing the published report and developed advocacy tool. Advocacy efforts will be informed by the outcomes of the research conducted.

Launch Training – to introduce country teams to MTT model and global partners, and provide technical training and assistance on data collection and long-term follow-up. Main outcomes of the training include agreement on the design, timeline, work plan/milestones and deliverables of the project. In-country Research – country teams will begin project implementation and research, per timelines agreed upon during Launch Training. Technical Assistance – interim check-ins will be conducted by ITPC (via Skype, phone, e-mail, etc.) to provide further technical assistance to country teams and ensure progress is on track to meet milestones and deliverables.

title.narrative: 4 Participation of partner organization in or organization of local national regional or global stakeholder meetings

description.narrative: Participation of partner organization in or organization of local national regional or global stakeholder meetings is measured by the number of partner organisations that participate in meetings. Meetings are defined as advocacy meetings with local national regional or global stakeholders.

description.narrative: 4 # partner organisations that participated in or organized local/national/regional/global stakeholder meetings is measured by the number of partner organisations. Meetings are advocacy meetings with local/national/regional/global stakeholders.

comment.narrative: Both national partners involved in community research participated in national meetings to discuss results and advocate for evidence-based policy change

description.narrative: Trained service providers is measured through 2 indicators. The first measures the number of service providers trained. Service providers provide social services, including psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, or health NGO or public sector services. The counselling part of VCT services is excluded. They are individuals within local partner organisations within BtG that provide services, as well as from indirect service providers that receive training from BtG local partners for instance other NGO-run clinics, private clinics, state-run services, etc. The second measures the number of legal service providers trained including paralegal services

2A # of service providers trained. This is the number of individual service providers meaning staff members, trained by alliance partner and/or by a country partner. Total # is the number of people trained by alliance partner and number of people trained by partners. Service providers provide social (including psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, NOT the counselling part of VCT services), or health(NGO or public sector) services. They are individuals within local partner organisations within BtG that provide services, as is part of this indicator, testing for TB, STIs. Data collection: based on the report of CBOs. Partner documentation tool and outreach registration tool. 10 well as from indirect service providers that receive training from BtG local partners (e.g. other NGO-run clinics, private clinics, state-run services, etc).
2B # legal service providers trained including paralegal services
